[@matt](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) 

I've been playing around with Mutant more often and noticed that `when()` operates like a ternary function, but I've noticed that both `a()` and `b()` are called in something like:

```js
when(true, a(), b()) // both a() and b() are called

// vs

true ? a() : b() // only a() is called
```

I know this is just a feature of JavaScript and don't expect Mutant to deal with it, but is there a way to get the same behavior of ternary functions where only one function is called?

I was thinking something like this might work:

```js
when(true, (() => a()), (() => b()))
```

But it's pretty hacky and I don't think it even works. Do you have a recommended solution? For context, I'm trying to resolve [this issue with Patchbay](https://github.com/ssbc/patchbay/issues/231#issuecomment-412362473).
